questions.question: What is membrane potential?
options: Voltage difference across cell membrane (inside relative to outside)
The energy stored in chemical gradients only
The pressure difference across membranes
Only present in neurons, not other cells
questions.explanation: Membrane potential (Vₘ) is the electrical potential difference between interior and exterior of a cell, typically -20 to -90 mV (negative inside). Results from unequal distribution of ions and selective membrane permeability.

questions.question: What primarily determines the resting membrane potential in animal cells?
options: Potassium diffusion through leak channels, with contribution from Na⁺/K⁺ pump
Only sodium gradient determines resting potential
Calcium channels maintain resting potential
Chloride is the main determinant in all cells
questions.explanation: Resting potential (~-70 mV) is close to K⁺ equilibrium potential (Eₖ ~ -90 mV) because membrane is most permeable to K⁺ at rest (through leak channels). Na⁺/K⁺ pump contributes electrogenically (3 Na⁺ out, 2 K⁺ in).

questions.question: What is the Nernst equation and what does it calculate?
options: Eₓ = (RT/zF) ln([X]out/[X]in); calculates equilibrium potential for specific ion
Calculates resting membrane potential from multiple ions
Determines energy required for active transport
Measures osmotic pressure across membranes
questions.explanation: The Nernst equation gives the voltage at which an ion is at electrochemical equilibrium (no net movement). Eₓ = (RT/zF) ln([X]ₒ/[X]ᵢ) where R=gas constant, T=temperature, z=ion charge, F=Faraday constant. At 37°C, simplifies to Eₓ = (61.5/z) log([X]ₒ/[X]ᵢ) mV.

questions.question: What is the Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz (GHK) equation?
options: Calculates membrane potential considering multiple ions weighted by their permeabilities
Same as Nernst but for single ions only
Calculates ion flux rates through channels
Determines pump stoichiometry and energy use
questions.explanation: Vₘ = (RT/F) ln( (Pₖ[K⁺]ₒ+Pₙₐ[Na⁺]ₒ+P꜀ₗ[Cl⁻]ᵢ) / (Pₖ[K⁺]ᵢ+Pₙₐ[Na⁺]ᵢ+P꜀ₗ[Cl⁻]ₒ) ). Considers relative permeabilities (P). At rest, Pₖ >> Pₙₐ, so Vₘ ≈ Eₖ. During action potential, Pₙₐ increases dramatically.

questions.question: What happens to membrane potential if extracellular K⁺ concentration increases?
options: Depolarization (less negative) as Eₖ becomes less negative, Vₘ follows
Hyperpolarization (more negative) as potassium leaves cells
No change because Na⁺ maintains potential
Cells immediately die from potassium toxicity
questions.explanation: Increased [K⁺]ₒ reduces K⁺ gradient, Eₖ becomes less negative (closer to zero). Since resting Vₘ tracks Eₖ due to high K⁺ permeability, cells depolarize. This occurs in hyperkalemia and affects cardiac rhythm.

questions.question: What are graded potentials versus action potentials?
options: Graded: local, decremental, variable amplitude; Action: all-or-none, non-decremental, fixed amplitude
Both are identical with different names
Graded: only in muscles; Action: only in neurons
Action potentials are smaller than graded potentials
questions.explanation: Graded potentials (postsynaptic, receptor, pacemaker): local changes from ligand/mechanically-gated channels, decay with distance. Action potentials: rapid, large depolarizations from voltage-gated channels, propagate without decay due to regeneration.

questions.question: What is the role of the Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase in maintaining resting potential?
options: Direct electrogenic contribution and maintaining ion gradients for leak channels
Only maintains gradients without electrical effect
Actually reduces resting potential by pumping ions
Has no role in resting potential maintenance
questions.explanation: 1) Direct electrogenic effect: 3 Na⁺ out, 2 K⁺ in creates net outward current. 2) Maintains gradients: without pump, gradients run down via leak channels, Vₘ depolarizes toward 0 mV. Contributes ~-10 mV directly in some cells.

questions.question: What determines ion permeability across membranes?
options: Number and state (open/closed) of specific ion channels
Only lipid solubility of ions
Membrane thickness alone
Temperature but not channel proteins
questions.explanation: Permeability (P) = (number of channels × open probability × single channel conductance) / membrane area. Different cells express different channel types. At rest: high Pₖ (leak channels). During action potential: Pₙₐ then Pₖ increase sequentially.

questions.question: What is electrochemical equilibrium and when does it occur?
options: When electrical and chemical forces balance for an ion (no net movement); at Nernst potential
When all ions have equal concentrations inside and out
Only during action potentials, not at rest
When ATP production equals consumption
questions.explanation: Electrochemical equilibrium: chemical gradient driving ion in one direction equals electrical gradient driving it opposite direction. At Vₘ = Eₓ for that ion. No energy required to maintain (but energy needed to establish gradients via pumps).

questions.question: How do cardiac muscle cells maintain stable resting potential compared to neurons?
options: Higher P꜀ₗ (chloride) and different channel expression creates more stable resting potential
Have identical resting potentials to neurons
No resting potential - constantly depolarizing
Only use calcium, not potassium for resting potential
questions.explanation: Cardiac myocytes have Vᵣ ≈ -90 mV (more negative than neurons) due to: 1) High Iₖ₁ (inward rectifier K⁺ channels), 2) Significant chloride conductance, 3) Different leak channel isoforms. This stability prevents spontaneous depolarizations that could trigger arrhythmias.
